request.description: Get all status for all residents at all times. We're not using this API for frontend user

This API will return the latest status of all residents (breath rate, heart rate, etc). Use this API to give frontend user the live data.

It requires JWT token, so the user only sees the status of their residents

This API is for viewing the alert settings for each community. We can find the same settings located at system alerts on VeriCare website.

Note that each community will only have one settings for all of their residents (same as VeriCare).

response.name: /alert_settings/

request.description: This API call is for updating the alert settings for each resident

response.name: /alert_settings/

request.description:
This API call is used to view all alerts (resolved, unresolved, in progress) at all times. We will use this to view alert history. It is similar as in the page 4 of the VeriCare website.

The header requires the JWT token, the result only shows the residents in the community that provides the JWT.

This API call is to change the state or assign/change a caregiver of an alert.

Optional body (one of the state and caregiver_id must be provided):

1.  state: (resolved, in_progress, unresolved)
2.  caregiver_id
3.  description
    

The header requires the JWT token, the result only shows the residents in the community that provides the JWT.

This API call will give you unresolved alerts in the last 5 minutes. This should be used as alerts pop up similar as the pop up alert of VeriCare website. The unresolved alert that is longer than 5 minutes will not appear

The header requires the JWT token, the result only shows the residents in the community that provides the JWT.

This API will give us all unresolved and in progress alerts. On the VeriCare website, this is located at the bottom of the first page.

The header requires the JWT token, the result only shows the residents in the community that provides the JWT.

exec: tests["Access token was not empty"] = jsonData.access_token !== undefined;

request.description:
This is the API to login. It will find the data from the community database and grants the access token.

Required body:

1.  email: COMMUNITY_EMAIL
2.  password: COMMUNITY_PASSWORD

exec: tests["Access token was not empty"] = jsonData.access_token !== undefined;

request.description:
This is the API to login. It will find the data from the community database and grants the access token.

Required body:

1.  email: COMMUNITY_EMAIL
2.  password: COMMUNITY_PASSWORD

This is the API to create new user. All the fields must be filled.

Required body:

1.  email
2.  password: -> password will be hashed before storing it to database
3.  role: one of \["individual", "community_admin", "community_staff"\]
4.  entity_name
5.  address
6.  city
7.  state
8.  zip_code
9.  phone_number

response.name: auth/signup

request.description: This API is not meant to use from the client side. It is the webhook endpoint for sending status data from VeriCare to our API.

This API is used to generate report chart. It will returns HTML string. It is the same as the third page of VeriCare website.

Required query parameters:

format: "html" or "pdf"

type: "daily", "2weeks", or "trending"

date: "YYYY-MM-DD"

This API is to view all residents in a community. This will be useful for filtering status, alerts, reports, etc. So the community can only see their corresponding residents.

The header requires the JWT token, the result only shows the residents in the community that provides the JWT.

This API is to assign a resident to a community. We don't use this API on the frontend because we're the one who assign resident to community. We might need another interface for this logic.

The header requires the JWT token, the result only shows the residents in the community that provides the JWT.

response.name: /community_resident/<communityId>

request.description:
This API is to delete a resident from the community.

The header requires the JWT token, it only deletes the residents in the community that provides the JWT.

response.name: /community_resident/<communityId>

request.description:
This API is used to create new caregiver in a community.

It needs to have a body consisting of 3 optional fields:

1.  first_name
2.  last_name
3.  role
    

The header requires the JWT token.

This API is used to view all caregivers in a community.

The header requires the JWT token, the result only shows the caregiver in the community that provides the JWT.

This API is used to view a caregiver given its id

The header requires the JWT token, the result only shows the caregiver in the community that provides the JWT.

This API is used to update a caregiver given its id. You need to put the update fields on the request body.

The header requires the JWT token, it only updates the caregiver in the community that provides the JWT.

This API is used to delete a caregiver given its id.

The header requires the JWT token, it only deletes the caregiver in the community that provides the JWT.

API to create/add new resident. This API also adds the row in the community.residents table and automatically creates resident alert settings.

Fields (haven't implement required fields functionality):

1.  veri_id
2.  name
3.  gender
4.  age
5.  mobility_level
6.  require_repositioning
7.  pet_type
8.  weight
9.  room_id
10.  address
11.  additional_information
12.  family_contact_person
13.  family_relationship
14.  family_contact_number
15.  physician
16.  physician_contact_number
17.  wellness_nurse
18.  timezone
19.  installation_date
20.  assigned_bed_sensor
21.  active_now
    

The header requires the JWT token, the result will creates the resident and assign it to the community that provides the JWT.

API to get all residents in a community.

The header requires the JWT token, the result only shows the residents in the community that provides the JWT.

request.description:
API to get specific resident in a community.

The header requires the JWT token, the result only shows the resident in the community that provides the JWT.

API to change resident information.

The header requires the JWT token, the result only updates the resident in the community that provides the JWT.

response.name: /resident/<residentId>

request.description:
API to delete resident. This will also removes the resident from community.resident database (removed from community) and the settings from resident.alert.settings.

It requires JWT token.

This API is used to view the alert settings on a given resident id.

The header requires the JWT token, the result only shows the resident settings in the community that provides the JWT.

response.name: /resident_alert_settings/<residentId>

request.description:
This API is used to modify the alert settings on a specific resident.

The header requires the JWT token, it only updates the resident settings in the community that provides the JWT.

response.name: /resident_alert_settings/<residentId>

request.description:
API for inbed_status pie chart.

This API requires JWT token, so it only calculates the aggregation based on the residents from the logged in community.

query.description: get the counts from start date to now

request.description:
This API is used to get the alert counts grouped by residents. The default date range of result alerts is 24 hours ago to now.

This API requires JWT token, so it only calculates the aggregation based on the residents from the logged in community.

query.description: get the counts from start date to now

request.description:
API for hourly alerts dashboard.

This API requires JWT token, so it only calculates the aggregation based on the residents from the logged in community.

API for daily alerts dashboard.

This API requires JWT token, so it only calculates the aggregation based on the residents from the logged in community.
This API is used to get all the history changes of an alert.
